hints_html:
What technique of integration does one generally use when integrating a product of functions?

What makes computing the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int xe^{x^2}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

very different?
hints_latex:
What technique of integration does one generally use when integrating a
product of functions?

What makes computing the integral

\begin{align*}
\int xe^{x^2}\,dx
\end{align*} very different?
hints_raw:
What technique of integration does one generally use when integrating a product of functions?
What makes computing the integral
:<math>
\int xe^{x^2}\,dx
</math>
very different?
question: 1 (i)
sols_html:
Use integration by parts with

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle u = x \quad\text{and}\quad dv = e^{2x}\end{aligned}\]

we obtain:

\[\begin{aligned} \int xe^{2x}\,dx &= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \int \frac{1}{2}e^{2x}\,dx \\ &= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \frac{1}{4}e^{2x} + C \\ &= \frac{(2x - 1)e^{2x}}{4} + C\end{aligned}\]

where \(C\) is a constant.
sols_raw:
Use integration by parts with
:<math>\displaystyle
u = x \quad\text{and}\quad dv = e^{2x}
</math>
we obtain:

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int xe^{2x}\,dx &= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \int \frac{1}{2}e^{2x}\,dx \\
&= \frac{xe^{2x}}{2} - \frac{1}{4}e^{2x} + C \\
&= \frac{(2x - 1)e^{2x}}{4} + C
\end{align}
</math>

where <math>C</math> is a constant.
